BE

The betting odds have shifted quite dramatically this morning. The odds of a ‘Remain’ vote have risen to 84 per cent according to Betfair. Around an hour ago, the implied probability of a pro-EU vote was 78 per cent, reports Mehreen Khan on fastFT.
“There’s so much money coming in on the market that the odds are fluctuating quite a lot this morning, but momentum is firmly behind Remain”, said Naomi Totten at Betfair, which is a betting exchange rather than a traditional bookmaker.
Sterling has now leapt 1.2 per cent against the dollar so far today to $1.4880, its highest level since December. The pound has rebounded 5.2 per cent since it hit a two-month low on Thursday last week.

BE

That's via one of the 17 or 18 Brexit liveblogs we're running on FT.com this morning.

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 266.98, up 17.88 (+7.18%), High: 267.20, Low: 252.80, Volume: 1.04m

BE

BE

As a result, it moves like a cork in a flushing toilet. I'm loathe to note any more less than 20% in this context.

11:19 am
BE

However, there's some sellside around to justify today's move, should it need justified.

BE

Morgan Stanley says "Amazon, pah!"

BE

Although Amazon may prove a formidable competitor in Ocado's
home market long term, it could also be the much needed catalyst
to get Ocado Smart Platform off the ground. So in the medium
term, we believe Amazon could actually be a net positive for Ocado
shares. We stay OW, PT 420p (~70% upside).
What's new? AmazonFresh – the grocery service already active in the US –
just launched for Amazon Prime members in 69 London postcodes. Until now,
Amazon UK has been selling groceries via (i) Pantry (dry grocery / HPC offer)
and (ii) Prime Now (offering a limited selection of dry & chilled groceries).
Key conclusion: We think Ocado in the long term can be a net beneficiary of
Amazon's foray into grocery. While a successful AmazonFresh in the UK could
shave 90-110p from our Ocado valuation, this impact would most likely be
offset if the Amazon threat prompted just 3 additional partners to sign with
Ocado's Smart Platform (OSP) over the next few years.
Share of the pie vs. size of the pie. Ocado today captures ~15% of the UK
online grocery market. But what matters for its top-line growth more than its
online market share is the pace of the channel shift. We believe that Amazon's
foray into UK online grocery could help grow the segment market and that if
Amazon – covered by Brian Nowak – succeeds in its UK grocery venture, most
at risk is the 94% of the market still not online.

11:20 am
BE

Superior proposition vs. peers. Ocado's customer proposition is best-in-
class (on service, range, convenience and ability to leverage data), creating a
very loyal customer base (Exhibit 5). Same-day delivery could also be available
throughout London via Ocado's game-changing fourth central fulfilment
centre (CFC) (due end 2017 with £1.2bn of sales capacity). If AmazonFresh
succeeds, we think it will most likely take share from weaker customer
propositions (with limited ranges and lower convenience) – as will Ocado.
Competitive advantage. Amazon's Prime service, brand awareness and
marketplace are key assets but we are not as confident about an edge in fresh
logistics. Its UK Fresh offer seems priced competitively, but slightly less so after
delivery fees. We think Ocado already makes an adjusted 4% EBIT margin on
its core UK business, despite competitors heavily subsidising online and before
operating more efficient CFCs. Thus we think Ocado can still grow in a context
where competitors with higher cost bases choose to operate at cost.
Catalyst effect. Outside France and the UK, online grocery is still too small a
segment to be disruptive, in our view. Amazon could conceivably act as a
catalyst, pushing retailers abroad to seriously consider Ocado's OSP.

PM

game-changing fourth central fulfilment centre

PM

11:22 am
BE

While the numbers released as part of Ocado’s 1H results (Tuesday 28 June) will of course be of interest, we expect at least as much attention on a number of key strategic questions, such as the progress made towards signing an international deal, the opening of CFC3, as well as any update on the new agreement with Morrison. A lot of the potential value in the Ocado investment case rests on the possibility of international partnerships – it is difficult to have a confident view about their likely appearance, although their absence so far does not breed great confidence. However, we tend to think that the value of the existing business accounts for a clear majority of Ocado’s valuation and that the current share price does not incorporate a huge value for these potential agreements. We reiterate our Equal Weight stock rating and 290p price target.

11:35 am

Here's what Canaccord said at the time ......

PM

June 14

BE

Conventional operations: FY production guidance maintained at 2500-2700 boed with operating costs still expected to be c.$30/boe.

Balance sheet: The company has continued to deleverage its balance sheet over the past year or more through a combination of farm-outs, bond buybacks, bond amortisation, and it currently has £23.6m cash. IGas is looking to strengthen its balance sheet further and it has been in discussions with bondholders with a view to extending the debt maturities (currently 2018), deferring some interest payments, and waiving of some covenants.

The company is in discussion with a number of potential investors and is looking at a range of options for cash and earning accretive transactions including farm-outs and asset portfolio management. These discussions are aimed at realising an appropriate capital structure that is sustainable in the current oil price environment, and allowing the company to reach the full potential of the conventional reserves. IGas sees a number of opportunities to increase conventional production by c.700 boed, net of decline, by January '18.

Shale: IGas has an extensive UK shale gas position of c.1m gross acres (post 14th Round) in the key areas of the Bowland shale play in England together with up to $255m gross carried work programme. The next likely operational activities for the company are expected to be the drilling of two carried wells in H1 ’17 at its Springs Road site in the East Midlands.

Canaccord Genuity view

These look like sensible actions from the company to 'right size' its capital structure, adjust appropriately to any potential bond covenant tests, and provide the opportunity to get the best from the conventional producing assets. The shale gas potential provides the primary upside for the company and we expect the remainder of the year to be dominated by industry wide permitting and operational preparation, leading to an upturn in on-the-ground operations in '17 across the sub-sector.

Valuation and rating

We maintain our TP of 45p/share and our Speculative BUY rating.

Luxury and Upper Upscale outperformed other segments; Economy least positive: Luxury (+7.9%), Upper Upscale (+4.0%), Upscale (+1.6%), Upper Midscale (+2.0%), Midscale (+2.0%), and Economy (+1.3%). Transient segment (individual business and leisure travelers) RevPAR was +1.7% (v. +1.0% last week) and Group segment RevPAR was +11.4% (v. +9.0% last week). The transient performance was mediocre and representative of the continued weakness in corporate demand.

11:47 am
BE

DS Smith continues to report strong growth in corrugated
volumes. While some of this may reflect market share gains, it
suggests that the European market remains in good shape. If
this level of demand growth can be maintained, the industry
should be able to cope with the new containerboard capacity
set to come on-stream over the next four years.

BE

DS Smith reported full-year (to April 2016) operating profit of £379m, 2% ahead of our
£372m forecast and 4% ahead of consensus of £366m. Stripping out the impact of
acquisitions (£20m) and FX (-£9m), organic profit growth was c.10% on organic revenue
growth of just 1%. This implies an incremental margin of c.87%. Reported operating
margins increased by 50bps.

Reported revenues increased by 6%. Adjusting for acquisitions (£306m) and FX (-
£101m), organic revenues grew by just 1% despite 3.1% growth in corrugated volumes.
This is similar to the trend recorded in H1. There is no sign of any impact from the 1-2%
increase in corrugated prices implemented by the industry in December/January last.

Performance was mixed across the divisions with revenues in the UK down 5% despite
“good” volume growth. This reflected in part the closure of the Wansbrough mill. In
Western Europe, like-for-like volumes were ahead of the group average with the Iberian
businesses in particular growing strongly. France was also good, offsetting weaker
conditions in Benelux. The company also reported good growth in Germany with some
weakness in northern Europe as a result of the Russian sanctions. The strong
performance in Central Europe and Italy relates mainly to the impact of the Duropack
acquisition.

Adjusted EPS increased by 12% to 27.4p. The company increased its full-year dividend by
12% to 12.8p.

BE

Net debt increased to £1,099m at end-April, implying a net debt/EBITDA of 2.0x, the
upper limit of the company’s target range. This reflects the impact of £433m in
acquisitions and capex of £201m (160% of depreciation). The company generated
positive working capital inflows of £56m, reflecting its ongoing strong performance in
this area.

11:48 am
BE

And, oh, Jefferies.

BE

For its coverage of European containerboard capacity concerns.

BE

European containerboard capacity concerns: Concerns have grown regarding
European containerboard pricing outlook, with 4.3mT (14%) of planned 2016-19 recycled
containerboard additions outstripping likely 2% pa demand growth. While DS Smith is short
paper (making c63% of 4mT paper consumed), any softness in containerboard is likely to
be mirrored in box prices, impacting DS Smith operating margins (9.4% in FY16F, within
8%-10% target range).

11:49 am
BE

Valuation: At 387p, DS Smith trades on cons FY17 c12.5x PE and 8x EV/EBITDA, a 15%-20%
premium to UK-listed packaging peers Smurfit Kappa and Mondi, which offer similar mix of
organic & M&A growth. While attracted to DS Smith's successful M&A record, on valuation
we remain at Hold, with preference for UK packaging peers Smurfit Kappa and Mondi.

BE

BE

 UK LFLs ex VAT ex fuel broadly in line with JPMe and consensus at
+0.3% after +0.9% in 4Q15 on stable comps. The 2-Y LFL was broadly
stable also at -1.0% after -0.8% in 4Q. This performance compares to
Morrison’s LFL ex fuel +0.7 (13-w to May 1) and Sainsbury’s LFLs ex
fuel -0.8% (12-weeks to June 4).

BE

 UK volumes +2.2% follows +3.3% in Q4; transactions +1.7% after
+2.8% in 4Q.

11:58 am
BE

 Farm Brands is performing ‘in line with expectations’, growing
volumes but with a 70bps deflationary impact on sales. Volume growth
in produce and meat outperforming the market by c.5%.

BE

 International LFLs ex VAT ex fuel a notch light of consensus 3.8%
but in line with JPMe at +3.0% (Europe +2.8%; Asia +3.3%).

BE

Jefferies with something more readable.

11:58 am
BE

Tesco's Q1 update was as expected, with LFL progress diluted by major price
reinvestment in the UK. At this juncture, our neutral view balances out
the progress made on trading momentum against uncertainties on freehold
repurchase requirements, the uncertainties implicit within the upcoming Asda
change of leadership and (to a much lesser extent) Amazon Fresh impact.
An in-line Q1 with UK LFL of +0.3% (JEFe/cons 0%/0.2%). International was a bit shy with
Europe LFL of 2.8% (JEFe/cons 3%/3.5%) and Asia at 3.3% (JEFe/cons 2.8%/3.8%). This is
consistent with ST consensus expectations, and Tesco confirmed its comfort with 16/17
group clean EBIT of £1,176m (JEFe £1,132m). Inevitably this is a ceteris paribus view that
does not reference potential changes at Asda.

BE

Yes, we are impacting discounters. Tesco is pleased with the boost that the March
launch of farm brands has had in the UK (with volume outperformance of 500bps in
produce and meat). Tesco quoted IRI as the source confirming that its growth was ahead
of peers in 9 out of 10 categories in Q1. The team is confident that momentum is building
sequentially, and the 6% reduction in the weekly basket cost achieved since September 2014
is a powerful mechanic. Nearly two years into the Dave Lewis tenure, Tesco has taken the
lead in the fight against discounters. Ranges are being drastically simplified (with obvious
opex benefits) and shelf pricing sharpened vs. promos dialled back (couponing fell 38% YoY
and multibuys almost halved). Retail basics (availability, queuing experience etc) are being
addressed and discounters' relative attraction diminished. Today's assertion that Tesco is
beating discounters, ex-space impacts, is a useful reminder of changing industry dynamics.

BE

Many variables = many outcomes. Tesco sees 'lots and lots and lots of opportunities
to reinvest in the customer offer and rebuild profitability'. At this juncture, we assume a
UK margin trajectory of 2.1%, 2.4% and 2.7% in the next three years. Major variables
currently underpinning our neutral view include uncertainty on the capital required for
further freehold rebuild, and the potential impact of Asda's mgmt. changes (with Asda being
Tesco's major source of share in the past year). On the latter, we note yesterday's WMT
presentation at our Nantucket conference referencing stepped up pricing coming in the UK
later this year.
